0.title: Adult Dosing
0.mono: Typhoid fever; Prophylaxis: 0.5 mL IM as a single dose; booster dose every 2 yr if re-exposure expected

1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono:
• safety and effectiveness have not been established in children below 2 years of age
  • Typhoid fever; Prophylaxis: 2 yr and older, 0.5 mL IM as a single dose; booster dose every 2 yr if re-exposure expected

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• acute infection or febrile illness; consider deferring vaccination
  • coagulation disorders, thrombocytopenia; intramuscular injection
  • continue to take precautions against exposure to typhoid organisms (i.e. avoid contact or ingestion of potentially contaminated food or water; vaccine protection is not universal
  • history of sensitivity to similar vaccines
  • impaired immune responsiveness; deficiency in ability to produce a humoral or cell-mediated immune response (either congenital or acquired immunodeficiency including treatment with immunosuppressive drugs or radiation)
  • special care should be taken to ensure that the vaccine is not injected into a blood vessel
  • vaccine adverse event reporting system: 1-800-822-7967, or http://www.vaers.org, and to manufacturer at 1-800-822-2463

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono:
• WHO: Compatible with breastfeeding.
  • Micromedex: Infant risk is minimal.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Dermatologic:Erythema (children 6.9%; adults 3% to 11%), Induration at injection site (children 2.9%; adults 5.1% to 18%), Injection site pain (children 14.3%; adults 26% to 56%), Tenderness, localized (children 13%; adults 93% to 98%)
  • Gastrointestinal:Nausea (1.9% to 8.2%)
  • Musculoskeletal:Myalgia (2% to 7.4%)
  • Neurologic:Headache (11% to 27%)
  • Other:Feeling feverish (children 2.9%; adults 3.1% to 11.1%), Malaise (4.1% to 37%)
Serious
  • Immunologic:Hypersensitivity reaction
  • Other:Serum sickness due to drug

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Typhoid Vi polysaccharide vaccine exerts its protective effect against Salmonella typhi, the pathogen of typhoid fever, by increasing the serum anti-capsular antibodies.

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
• General Information
    (injection) for IM use only; do not give IV
  • Intramuscular
    • immunization should occur at least two weeks prior to expected exposure
    • preferred injection site for adults is in the deltoid
    • preferred injection site for children is in either the deltoid or the vastus lateralis

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• This vaccine may cause nausea, vomiting, myalgia, headache, fever, or malaise.
  • Advise patient that this immunization should occur at least 2 weeks prior to expected exposure.
